overview.short: Kocuria rosea is a Gram-positive, catalase-positive, non-motile coccus within the Micrococcaceae, often producing pink to rose-colored colonies.
overview.clinical_context: Typically opportunistic; may be isolated from skin/soft tissue sites, blood cultures (often line-associated), and immunocompromised patients. Frequently confused with Micrococcus or coagulase-negative Staphylococcus.

species_markers.notes: Rose/pink pigmentation is a practical clue for K. rosea, but pigment intensity depends on incubation and medium.
Typical isolates are non-haemolytic; haemolysis suggests alternative taxa or unusual strains.

common_confusions.reason: Both may form tetrads and produce pigmented colonies; definitive ID often needed.
Catalase-positive Gram-positive cocci can be mistaken for CoNS when pigmentation is faint.

when_to_question_identification: Coagulase positivity suggests Staphylococcus aureus rather than Kocuria.
Marked beta haemolysis argues against K. rosea.
If repeatedly isolated from a sterile site, confirm by MALDI-TOF or sequencing due to frequent misidentification.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Rules out S. aureus when Gram-positive cocci in clusters are seen.
Most reliable routine method to identify Kocuria at species level.
Confirmatory option if clinically significant isolate or MALDI result is ambiguous.
